# Hiking networks {.smaller background-image="background-image.png" background-opacity="0.65"}

## Building a hiking network
### Start with regular lattice across study area
### Many topologies could be used

```{r}
library(sf)
library(igraph)
library(ggplot2)
library(patchwork)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)

source("raster-to-graph-functions-paper.R")

theme_set(theme_void()) 
theme_update(
  plot.margin = unit(c(1, 1, 2, 1), "mm"),
  plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, vjust = 2))

get_lattice <- function(dist, pts) {
  pts |>
    st_buffer(dist) |>
    st_contains(pts, sparse = FALSE) |>
    as.matrix() |>
    graph_from_adjacency_matrix(mode = "directed", diag = FALSE) |>
    set_vertex_attr("x", value = pts$x) |>
    set_vertex_attr("y", value = pts$y)
}

get_graph_plot <- function(G, main, crs = 2193) {
  return(ggplot() +
    geom_sf(data = G |> get_graph_as_line_layer(crs = 2193),
            lwd = 1, colour = "grey") +
    geom_sf(data = G |> vertex_attr() |> as.data.frame() |> 
              st_as_sf(coords = 1:2, crs = crs), size = 12,
              colour = "#191919", fill = "grey", shape = 21) +
    coord_sf(xlim = c(-270, 270) + 1e6, 
             ylim = c(-270, 270) + 1e6, expand = FALSE) +
    ggtitle(main)) +
    theme(
      plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#191919"),
    )
}

grid_pts <- expand_grid(x = -20:20 * 100 + 1e6, y = -20:20 * 100 + 1e6) |>
  as.data.frame() |>
  st_as_sf(coords = c("x", "y"), crs = 2193, remove = FALSE) 
  
hex_grid_pts <- grid_pts |>
  st_bbox() |> 
  st_make_grid(square = FALSE, what = "centers", cellsize = 107.457) |>
  st_as_sf() |>
  rename(geometry = x) |>
  st_set_crs(2193)

xy <- hex_grid_pts |> st_coordinates()
hex_grid_pts <- hex_grid_pts |>
  mutate(x = xy[, 1], y = xy[, 2])

graphs <- mapply(
  get_lattice,
  list(101, 150, 110),
  list(grid_pts, grid_pts, hex_grid_pts))
names(graphs) <- list("Rook's move", "Queen's move", "Hex")
```

```{r}
#| fig-width: 8
#| fig-height: 3.045
ggplots <- list()
for (n in names(graphs)) {
  ggplots[[n]] <- get_graph_plot(G = graphs[[n]], main = n)
}

wrap_plots(ggplots, nrow = 1) & theme(
  plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#191919"),
  text = element_text(colour = "white")
)
```

### We went with hexagonal at ~107m spacing

## Up $\neq$ down {background-image="klondike.jpg" background-opacity="0.65"}
### Slope is critical to movement, so attach heights to nodes and calculate slope in each direction along lattice edges
### Then apply a *hiking function* to estimate traversal times

::: aside
[People heading uphill in the Klondike gold rush 1897](https://www.nps.gov/klgo/learn/goldrush.htm) National Park Service, Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park, Candy Waugaman Collection, KLGO Library SS-126-8831
:::

## Completing and applying the network
### Assign edges *estimated traversal times* based on slope, the hiking function, and land cover (moraine or rock)
### Make the nodes and edges into a _directed graph_
### Then use various _graph algorithms_ to find, e.g., everywhere-to-everywhere shortest paths

## Betweenness centrality
### After some exploration, we landed on _betweenness centrality_ as a useful metric
### Counts how often each node appears on shortest paths between every other pair of nodes
&nbsp;

### &rarr; Indicator of relative likelihood of locations being visited

## 

![](fig-betweenness-map-1.png){fig-align="center"}

## Radius-limited betweenness
### Restrict betweenness centrality to nodes no more than some cost (i.e., _time_) apart
### _Much_ faster to calculate
### Also... it may have more value: perhaps relevant to how people navigate in such environments

##

![](fig-radius-limited-betweenness-1.png){fig-align="center"}

##

![](betweenness.png){fig-align="center"}

## Planning a path network?
### A way to reduce impact might be to plan paths
### _Experimental_ at this stage
### Based on a _minimum spanning tree_ approximation to an _arborescence_

::: aside
A minimum spanning tree is a subgraph with minimum total cost that reaches all the nodes in a network. An arborescence is the equivalent in a directed graph.
:::
